document.text: WITH PURCHASE OF 4 LIGHT BULBS  Appomattox County supervis ors and officials of the Va. De partment of Highways, Appo mattox Residency, heard twen ty-two requests for 3.55 miles of new additions and 19.80 miles for improvements during a public hearing Friday morning, the regular meeting day for su pervisors and the date of the an nual road request meeting. Three requests for new addit ions were made from residents of Cloverhill district for a total length of 1.45 miles. Stonewall district also had three requests for additions for a total of 1.25 miles and Southside district, two requests for a total of .85 miles. Six requests for road im provements for a total length of eight miles came from Clo verhill district four requests from Stonewall for a total of 6.30 miles and four requests from Southside district for a total of 5.50 miles. In other action Friday super visors head from about 30 tax payers in person and 1,000 pet ition with regard to the recent reassessment of property. One individual, speaking dir ectly to the board, is concerned about an increase of 65 in his assessment and feels that his is unequal taxation in relation to property adjacent or close to his own in Pamplin. Walter Henry, farmer of Stonewall district, says he is concerned with land-use, and that farmers taxe s are out of proportion sometimes to tax as sessments for land which is going to be used for develop ment, other than farming. Supervisors also approved an ordinance which dissolves the former Finance Board of the county and transfers those dut ies to the board of supervisors. Supervisors devoted a good deal of time to the entire ques tion of taxation. The rate for taxation is set each April and the board talked about possibi lities of tax revenue from a bumper strip on each automo bile, a tax on public utilities or extra sales tax. Board mem bers stated that their effort in this line are directed to  spreading taxes among all the people - those who own pro perty and those who do not so that the burden of county gov ernment and schooling can be shared by all who benefit. Earlier inthemeetingattorn- ey Robert Carter said he spoke for the delegation present in the Court House asking for clari- ficiation of the recent reas sessment. He asked tha t the tax be lowered from the present 3.00 per hundred evaluation. Cecil Ligon, merchant of Pamplin, said that his mission was to seek equalization and

document.text: Whooping cough is prevalent in this section. Mr. C. M. Strattons little girl has been very ill with whooping cough, so much so that for a time its life despared of.  Dr, Rrice was was promptly called ih,who soon checked the disease, and the little one is now restored to health. Mr. T. J. Stratton State inspec tor and sampler of fertilizers, has completed his labors for the sprjng season. Mr. Stratton reports that fertilizers have been very largely used all over the State this spring, and that he is satisfied that. Appo mattox farmers buy a larger per cent, of their goods direct from first lids for Gash, ilittu tile fui iiiefs of any, other section, of the State. Miss Belle Porter, of Farmville, who is visiting M ibb Lizzie Rice, was quite ill last week. Our people are jubilant over the result of the late election. The old Stonewall district did nobly, and is entitled to the banner. We are for Hoge Tyler for Gov ernor, Taylor Berry, of the old Dem ocratic free State of Amherst, for Lieutenant Governor, and for Thos. lit Martin for United States Senator. Ey r. Chap Jones was in the neigh borhood last Sunday. The Dr. visits us quite often of late. We are always glad to see him, but we cant help but think that there. is a lady stopping here to whom we are in debted for his frequent visits. S tonewall . Spanish Oaks, Va., June 7.

document.text: While Mr. B e r k l e y Wool- ride was attempting to mount lone of Mr. Joe OBriens horses last Sunday the animal bit him on the calf of the leg, causing a very painful wound and keep ing Mr. Woolridge from his  post of duty for several days _ r. Joel Hubbard, mail car rier on route 1, is seriously ill at his home. He returned home from his route last Wed nesday feeling very unwell He was in bed all day Thurs day and on Friday morning it was seen that he had received a paralytic stroke As we go to press he is said to be very low. The district board at Roa noke has reversed the Looal Board of Lynchburg in defer rin g registrants who have be-  coire married since May 18th last and now puts the newly weds in class 1. There are quiteanuinBer of these cases before the district board from this county, and just what will happen to our newly-weds is not known. Beginning next Sunday a. m. Bro. Callabam will preach a series of sermons on the origin, progress and present status of the Methodist Episcopal church, There will be nothing narrow or of the sectarian spirit in these set mons These sermons are given for general enlighten-1 ment on this subject. Every body invited to attend these services and friends and mem bers are urged to be present Sunday evening at 73U Miss Gold, of the faculty of A. A. H. 8, will conduct the Epworth  League. Special program for the evening. Mrs. 8. R. Martin, who has been in febbie health for some time, passed away Sunday atl her home near Trinity Ohurch in the 67th year of her age. The deceased was a woman of many virtues, full of the spirit of her Master and she wilt be missed by her c h u r c h and neighbors. She is survived by her husband, wLo is Supervisor for Stonewall district, and one son, Mr. Thomas Martin, of Ap pomattox. Her remains wtrej interred at her late home in the  presence of a very large crowd of friends and members of her family. Her pastor, Rev. A. 8.  J. Rice, assisted by Rev. J. M. Street, conducted the service. Tbe father of the deceased was  present, aged 92 years and ac live. _ _______

Ground weufher observations alone have been found to be Inadequate for dying use. and the hlgh-altltude ob servations have also been found use ful in making the regular weather forecasts. In fact, the wenther seems to brew at the higher levels, and the observations, obtained by small bal loons and kites, often give Informa tion unobtainable nt the level of the earths surface. 43 Balloon Stations Send Data. The data used In the npper-atr weather maps come to the weather bureau from forty-three halloon sta tions throughout the country. The army has eighteen, while the navy tins ten balloon stations and one air- nlane observer. The wenther burenu also receives alr-aloft reports of temperature and humidity from five stations where kites are sent up with raeteorollglcal In struments. As kites are dependent upon wind, the wenther bureau Is about to try out a small captive bal loon. lust large enough to carry the oecessury Instruments, at Due West, S. Is dearly shown by these kite reports. One recent re- laid from Orosheck, Texas, showed three strata of air-In an altitude of 1,800 meters. A meter Is a little more than three feet. The complete aero- logical observation map gives wind direction, velocity, kind and direction of clouds, and visibility as at surface. 250 meters above, 500 meters. 1,000 meters, 1,500 meters, 2,000 meters, 3,000 meters and 4,000 meters above. The balloons sometimes achieve much higher altitudes. The origin of the wind, whether polar or tropical. It is alleged that such proceedings as were carried on four years ago were very distasteful to many of the citizens of the county and for that reason the rank and file of voters are slow to express their choice for fear of the recurrence of hostile feeling. While no doubt man j have de cided views a to whom they will vote for, but little or no pub lic demonstrations have taken place throughout the county and while a few public gatherings have been held, the attendance at these meetings have been small and little interest in such meetings have been manifested. For the house of delegates, Col. A. J. Terrell is opposed by D- N. Gannaway, both of Buck ingham. Colonel Terrell being a candidate for what is called the organizations forces and Mr, Gannaway representing t h e antis. In this, like other county contests, there has been no issue and the fight hangs chiefly on personalities. In some quarters, the question of the short ballot issue has been in jected in which Mr. Gannaway ias declared himself as opposed to the short ballot, while no such statement has come from Mr. Terrell other than he is for the administration policies. As the short ballot, is an administra tion policy, however, it is regard ed that Mr. Terrell is for it, and su far, that is about the main is sue involved between the two candidates for that office. With but four more days be fore election more activity is teen on every hand and the poli tical pot is warming up to a con siderable degree in some of the local fights. For treasurer R. L. Burke is opposed by Dr. D. N. r wyman for commissioner of revenue Richard OBrien is op posed by George Purdum for supervisor Don Moses and C. S McDearmon are both candidates for Southside district to be made vacant by D. N. Twyman, the ncumbent, who is running for treasurer in Cloverhill district F. A- OBrien, the incumbent, is opposed by E. M. Drinkard, ant n Stonewall district Sam Ander on, the incumbent, is being op- tost d by A. B. Thornhill. During the past few days quite i contention has arisen over an ict of the registrars who have either by error of ignorantly sent rat two different kinds of in- structions to voters who wish to I vote by mail, this vote will  be heavy. document.text: VIRGINIA In the Circuit Court of Appomattox County, May 19th, 1956. Mamie Lee Hogg vs. Lawson J. Williams, et als. Whereas the object of this suit is to partition in one of the modes prescribed by law the land in Appo mattox County, Virginia, of which William P. Jennings died seized and the papers in this cause were refer red to C. W. Smith, one of the com missioners of this Court to make certain inquiries and report to the Court, and said commissioner hav ing made said inquiries and filed his report on April 21, 1956, re porting that said William P. Jen nings died intestate seized of 56.25 acres of land, more or less, lying in Stonewall District, Appomattox county, Virginia, not disposed of by his heirs that one of said heirs is Sallie Benson, a non-resident of Virginia, living in Baltimore, Mary land, whose street and number is not now known, and her interest in said land is 1180 of the whole that said land was sold for delin quent taxes and redeemed by Mamie Lee Hogg, alienee of some of the heirs and she should be reimbursed the sum she paid to redeem said land and also the taxes she herself paid on said land! that the fee simple value of said land is 500.- OO that Mamie Lee Hoggs inter est being 1120 of said land can be conveniently divided from the rest of said land and allotted to her but she will take the whole of said land and pay the others for their interest therein such sum as fixed by the Court to be fair and proper which the Court finds to be 920 of the fee simple value and that 100.00 is a proper fee to be allowed W. E. Hogg for instituting and conductihg this suit the inter est of the heirs who have not an swered, pleaded or demurred to the bill of complaint to be charged with their proportionate part there of, which report was confirmed and the offer of Mamie Lee Hogg ac cepted by a decree entered May 19th, 1956, except as to said Sallie Benson who has not been served with process or proceeded against by order of publication and in said decree it was ordered that an order of publication be published once a week for four successive weeks in the Times-Virginian against the said Sallie Benson requiring her to ap pear in this said Court within ten days after due publication of said order and show cause if any she can why the said report of C. W. Smith, commissioner, filed as aforesaid and the findings an action of the Court thereon should not be confirmed. It is ordered that said Sallie Benson appear in our said Court within ten days after due publica tion hereof and show cause if av she can why the said report and findings an action of the Court thereon should not he confirmed. It is further ordered that this order Te published once a week for four successive weeks in the Times- Virginian, a newspaper published in Appomattox, Virginia, a copy mail- ed to said Sallie Benson, Baltimore, Maryland, her last known address, and a copy posted as the law di rects. Teste C. W. Smith, Clerk. A copy. Teste C. W. iSmith, Clerk.

document.text: Tuesday, Nov. 8, is General Election day in Virginia, and a last minute effort is being made to get out a sizeable vote for Appomattox County. There are approximately 2,500 eligible voter in the county, but thus far there has been a min imum of interest, and the size of the actual vote is uncertain. To be elected are unopposed candi dates for the State Senate and the House of Delegates, and a slate of unopposed nominees for county of fices. Polling places will open at 6 A. M. and close at 6 P. M. There are ten precincts in the county. The candidates, all Democrats, are as follows For the State Senate, Chas. T. Moses. For the House of Delegates John B. Boatwright. For Commonwealths Attorney George Abbitt, Jr. For County Treasurer John G. Plunkett. For Commissioner of the Revenue J. H. OBrien. For Sheriff David T. Robertson. For Supervisor in Southside Dis trict F. L. Murphy. For Supervisor in the Stonewall District Otho W. Martin, Jr. For Supervisor in the Colver Hill District Richard Webb. For Justice of the Peace, South- side District Cree to be elected T. W. Moses, Mrs. Lucille S. Con ner and E. T Guill. The officials to be elected Tues day will take office in January. In appealing for a good turn-out of voters next Tuesday, the quality of the candidates listed and the im portance of the eounty maintaining a record for a large vote, were cited as reasons for everyone making an effort to cast their ballots.

document.text: tries would make available job opportunities in our area. Simultaneously with the start up operations of Virginia Fibre the county of Appomattox experienced widespread odor problems originating from this plant. As the Appomattox County Board of Supervisors will not meet before the hearing as of October 7 relative to this problem, as Supervisor of the Stonewall District of Appomat tox County, I can not stress too strongly the concern and anxiety of my constituency over the strong odor produced by the operation of this plant. According to location, the Stonewall District is immedi ately across the James River from the plant on the northw estern side of the county. As a member of the Appomattox County Board of Supervisors, I request that the Virginia Fibre Company and The Air Pollution Control Board develop an accelerated schedule whereby this problem may be abated at the earliest possible date. Sincerely yours, i Otho W. Martin, Jr., Supervisor, Stonewall District, Appomattox County

document.text: TO VOTERS OF STONEWALL DISTRICT  I have filed my declaration of candidacy to en ter the Democratic Primary of July 9, for re-election as Super visor of the Stonewall District of Appomattox County. 1 con sider it a great privilege to serve the people of the Stone wall District and appreciate their conficence and trust in al lowing me to represent them on the County Board of Superviaars during the last eight years. In filing my candidacy for re-elec tion, I look forward to serving them on the Board of Super visors for another term. I have always tried to serve the people of this district, without par tiality, to the best of my ability, and will continue to do so if re elected. O. W. Martin, Jr. 4-11-lp
